standard_metadata.standard_description: Find the area of right triangles, other triangles, special quadrilaterals, and polygons by composing into rectangles or decomposing into triangles and other shapes; apply these techniques in the context of solving real-world and mathematical problems.

question.content: Look at the image below.     **What is the area of the parallelogram?**   square units

images.alt: A parallelogram. The segment representing the height of the parallelogram is in the middle of the figure, splitting the figure in 2 parts. The base of the parallelogram is 7 units and the height of the parallelogram is 5 units. The diagonal side length is 6 units.

hints.content: Let's imagine we cut the parallelogram on the dotted line. We could slide part of the shape to make a rectangle.  Then we could find the area of the rectangle.
[[☃ image 1]]  The area of the parallelogram is the same as the area of a $7$-unit by $5$-unit rectangle.

images.alt: A parallelogram and a rectangle. Both figures have the same base and height. The segment representing the height of the parallelogram is in the middle of the figure, splitting the figure in 2 parts. The base of the parallelogram is 7 units and the height of the parallelogram is 5 units. The rectangle is made of the same 2 parts, but with the height segment shifted right to form the side of the rectangle. The base of the rectangle is 7 units and the height of the rectangle is 5 units.

hints.content: $\text{Area of parallelogram} = \text{Area of rectangle} = \text{base} \times \text{height}$
$\text{Area of parallelogram}  = 7 \times 5=35$ square units

The base of the parallelogram is 6 units and the height of the parallelogram is 4 units. The base of the rectangle is 6 units and the height of the rectangle is 4 units.

hints.content: $\text{Area of parallelogram} = \text{Area of rectangle} = \text{base} \times \text{height}$
$\text{Area of parallelogram}  = 6 \times 4=24$ square units

question.content: Look at the image below.    **Find the area of the parallelogram.**   square units

images.alt: A parallelogram. The segment representing the height of the parallelogram is in the middle of the figure, splitting the figure in 2 parts. The base of the parallelogram is 5 units and the height of the parallelogram is 7 units. The diagonal side length is 8 units.

hints.content: Let's imagine we cut the parallelogram on the dotted line. We could slide part of the shape to make a rectangle.  Then we could find the area of the rectangle.
[[☃ image 1]]  The area of the parallelogram is the same as the area of a $7$-unit by $5$-unit rectangle.

images.alt: A parallelogram and a rectangle. Both figures have the same base and height. The segment representing the height of the parallelogram is in the middle of the figure, splitting the figure in 2 parts. The base of the parallelogram is 5 units and the height of the parallelogram is 7 units. The rectangle is made of the same 2 parts, but with the height segment shifted down to form the side of the rectangle. The base of the rectangle is 5 units and the height of the rectangle is 7 units.

hints.content: $\begin{align} \text{Area of parallelogram} &= \text{Area of rectangle}\\\\ &= \text{base} \times \text{height}\\\\ &= 7 \times 5 \end{align}$
The area of the parallelogram is $35$ square units

hints.content: $\text{Area of parallelogram} = \text{Area of rectangle} = \text{base} \times \text{height}$
$\text{Area of parallelogram}  = 14 \times 6=84$ square units

images.alt: A parallelogram and a rectangle. Both figures have the same base and height. The segment representing the height of the parallelogram is in the middle of the figure, splitting the figure in 2 parts. The base of the parallelogram is 4 units and the height of the parallelogram is 7 units. The rectangle is made of the same 2 parts, but with the height segment shifted down to form the side of the rectangle.
